title: Projects
text:
Click-Through Rate (CTR) Prediction
Built machine learning models in R and Python to predict ad click-through rates using a large digital marketing dataset with user, ad, and news-feed features.

Compared logistic regression, tree-based models, and gradient boosting
Evaluated models using AUC, recall, precision, and F1
Implemented feature engineering and cross-validation

title: Projects
text:
Skin Cancer Prediction
Developed statistical learning models to predict skin cancer using clinical and behavioral variables.

Used logistic regression with regularization (LASSO, ridge)
Performed model selection and cross-validation
Communicated findings through visualizations and a written report

title: Projects
text:
AI Chatbot for Investment Education
Designed an AI-powered chatbot to answer client questions for an investment platform.

Integrated large language models with WhatsApp via API
Implemented retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) using company resources
Focused on safe, educational responses compliant with regulations

title: About Me
text:
I am an undergraduate at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), double majoring in Statistics & Data Science and Economics. I love working at the intersection of analytics, technology, and business ‚Äî especially where data-driven insights can enhance decision-making and real-world outcomes.
My academic work blends statistical modeling, machine learning, and applied econometrics with a strong interest in how data products are built, deployed, and used. Whether it‚Äôs developing predictive models, building dashboards, or designing generative-AI tools, I enjoy turning complex data problems into clear, actionable solutions.

title: About Me
text:
Beyond Academics
Outside the classroom, I am deeply involved in the UCLA community:

Resident Assistant (RA) ‚Äî supporting residents, designing programming, and building inclusive communities

Latin American Student Organization (LASO) ‚Äî leadership roles focused on mentorship, cultural engagement, and event planning

Engineers Without Borders (EWB) ‚Äî supporting internal operations and member coordination

Active involvement in other campus and professional organizations

These experiences have strengthened my communication, project management, and leadership skills, and they inspire me to bring empathy and structure into every team I work with.

title: Click-Through Rate (CTR) Prediction
text:
Status: Work in progress

Modeling user click-through behavior using combined advertising and news-feed interaction data. Current work includes feature engineering, regularization, and gradient-boosting models with a focus on recall and F1 for imbalanced data.
‚Üê Back to Projects

title: CAPM vs Fama‚ÄìFrench 3-Factor Model
text:
We compare how well CAPM and the Fama‚ÄìFrench 3-factor model explain excess returns of a set of equities relative to a market index.

Estimate factor loadings and risk premia
Compare model fit and residual patterns
Discuss which model better captures cross-sectional return differences

title: Panel Analysis of U.S. Cigarette Consumption
text:
Using the Cigar dataset, this project models per-capita cigarette sales across 46 states from 1963‚Äì1992.
We compare:

Pooled OLS
Fixed effects
Random effects

The Hausman test and F-tests support the fixed effects model, which we use to estimate price elasticity and discuss taxation policy implications.

Developing a multi-agent, LLM-powered chatbot that uses retrieval-augmented generation to answer client questions for an investment platform, focusing on safe, compliant educational responses.

title: Alcohol, Music, Gender, and Oxytocin
text:
This project uses a 3√ó2√ó2 factorial design to test the effects of alcohol type, music genre, and gender on blood oxytocin levels. We fit a three-way ANOVA and check all model assumptions.

Gender explains ~99% of the variance in oxytocin response.
Alcohol type and music genre show no meaningful main or interaction effects.

title: Macroeconomic Drivers of U.S. Nominal GDP
text:
This project fits multiple regression models linking nominal GDP to unemployment, inflation, the federal funds rate, money supply, and consumer confidence.
We focus on:

Multicollinearity diagnostics (VIF)
AIC-based model selection
Residual and specification checks

title: Skin Cancer Risk Prediction
text:
Status: Work in progress

Building predictive models using demographic, clinical, and behavioral variables to estimate skin cancer risk. The project explores logistic regression with LASSO and ridge penalties, feature selection, cross-validation, and calibration checks.
‚Üê Back to Projects

title: UFO Sightings and Political Alignment in the U.S.
text:
Status: Work in progress

This project analyzes UFO sighting records from the National UFO Reporting Center to study whether state political alignment is associated with differences in sighting frequency.
Early results show:

Democratic-leaning states tend to report higher average sightings.

Mann‚ÄìWhitney, chi-square, and Poisson regression all support this pattern.

Narrative descriptions and sighting characteristics (shape, duration) appear similar across political groups.

Upcoming work includes adjusting for population, incorporating additional state-level covariates, and expanding the text analysis of witness narratives.
